options.title: -A
options.description: Show the address of any protocol control blocks associated with sockets; useful for debugging e.g. with the -P flag. When used with the -r flag it shows the internal addresses of the routing table. Only the super-user can see these addresses; unprivileged users will see them as 0x0.

options.title: -a
options.description: With the default display, show the state of all sockets; normally sockets used by server processes are not shown.

options.title: -B
options.description: With the default display, show buffer sizes for TCP sockets. This includes the send window size, receive window size and congestion window size.

options.title: -b
options.description: With the interface display (options -I or -i), show bytes in and out, instead of packet statistics.

options.title: -c count
options.description: Display count updates, then exit. This option has no effect unless -w is specified as well.

options.title: -d
options.description: With either the interface display (options -I or -i) or an interval (option -w), show only the number of dropped packets.

options.title: -e
options.description: With either the interface display (options -I or -i) or an interval (option -w), show only the number of errors on the interface.

options.title: -F
options.description: When showing routes, only show routes whose gateway are in the same address family as the destination.

options.title: -f address_family
options.description:
Limit statistics or address control block reports to those of the specified address_family.

The following address families are recognized:

Address Family Constant Description inet AF_INET IP Version 4 inet6 AF_INET6 IP Version 6 local AF_UNIX Alias for unix mpls AF_MPLS MPLS unix AF_UNIX Local to Host (i.e., pipes)

options.title: -h
options.description: Use unit suffixes to reduce the number of digits shown with the -b and -w options.

options.title: -g
options.description: Show information related to multicast (group address) routing. By default, show the IP multicast virtual-interface and routing tables. If the -s option is also present, show multicast routing statistics.

options.title: -I interface
options.description: Show information about the specified interface; used with a wait interval as described below.

options.title: -i
options.description: Show the state of interfaces which have been auto-configured (interfaces statically configured into a system but not located at boot-time are not shown).

options.title: -l
options.description: With the default display, show only listening sockets. With the -g option, display wider fields for the IPv6 multicast routing table "Origin" and "Group" columns.

options.title: -M core
options.description: Extract values associated with the name list from the specified core instead of the running kernel.

options.title: -m
options.description: Show statistics recorded by the memory management routines (the network manages a private pool of memory buffers).

options.title: -N system
options.description: Extract the name list from the specified system instead of the running kernel.

options.title: -n
options.description: Show network addresses as numbers (normally netstat interprets addresses and attempts to display them symbolically). This option may be used with any of the display formats.

options.title: -P pcbaddr
options.description:
Display the contents of the protocol control block (PCB) located at the kernel virtual address pcbaddr. PCB addresses can be obtained using the -A flag. When used with the -v option, also print socket, domain and protocol specific structures. Only the super-user can use the -P option.

The -P option requires the ability to open /dev/kmem which may be restricted based upon the value of the kern.allowkmem sysctl(8).

options.title: -p protocol
options.description: Restrict the output to protocol, which is either a well-known name for a protocol or an alias for it. Some protocol names and aliases are listed in the file /etc/protocols. The program will complain if protocol is unknown. If the -s option is specified, the per-protocol statistics are displayed. Otherwise the states of the matching sockets are shown.

options.title: -q
options.description: Only show interfaces that have seen packets (or bytes if -b is specified).

options.title: -R
options.description: List all rdomains with associated interfaces and routing tables.

options.title: -r
options.description: Show the routing tables. The output is explained in more detail below. If the -s option is also specified, show routing statistics instead. When used with the -v option, also print routing labels.

options.title: -s
options.description: Show per-protocol statistics. If this option is repeated, counters with a value of zero are suppressed.

options.title: -T rtable
options.description: Select an alternate routing table to query. The default is to use the current routing table.

options.title: -t
options.description: With the -i option, display the current value of the watchdog timer function.

options.title: -u
options.description: Limit statistics or address control block reports to the AF_UNIX address family.

options.title: -v
options.description: Show extra (verbose) detail for the routing tables (-r), or avoid truncation of long addresses. When used with the -P option, also print socket, domain and protocol specific structures.

options.title: -W interface
options.description: (IEEE 802.11 devices only) Show per-interface IEEE 802.11 wireless statistics.

options.title: -w wait
options.description: Show network interface statistics at intervals of wait seconds.
